posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hello again, my good mates. This build was posted back in the old guild and has been slightly tweaked to be a little more effective. I was having trouble with low AC when I came up with it, so I traded Greatsword and some damage for Scimitar, which has a better threat range and works best in conjunction with DevCrit. This is a well-rounded half-orc. Rather than focusing on one single aspect of Barbarian might (Terrifying Rage, EDR and DevCrit) it has all three of them, but with lower DCs, still high enough to consistently kill those who are more vulnerable. With a versatile setting, this toon can strike the enemies where they are weak:

Has KD but no IKD, so heavy-strength melee types are quite hard to KD, on the other hand casters will get KDed a lot.

Has Terrifying Rage and 43 Ranks in intimidate but no ESF: Intimidate, so high-will save types will mostly resist your fury. However meleers, sneakers and other low-will creatures will almost certainly flee in horror.

Has DevCrit but only 32 ending Strength. Again, those more resilient with high fort saves will mostly make their saves, but casters and other low fortitude types will consistently get devastated.

As long as you know which weapons to use in which situation, this guy has enough to be a serious threat to all enemy types. Without further delay, here is the build:

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey, all!

With all the Barb / Bard / RDD builds that Tyr has begun posting, I had another fresh look at this guy and found something that could improve him a bit. Since you already have Devcrit, albeit at a not-so-high DC, Thundering Rage is a questionable investment, to say the least. So I decided to get Epic Prowess instead, gaining 1 AB effectively at the cost of some critical hit damage when raging. The OP has been edited to include that option.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: TyrTemplar
posts.content:
Nicely done, Max.

Good call on the EP vs. Thundering: a nice wholesome AB 45, makes for a good warrior. Raging barbarians are very cool, and your Dev.Crit DC (which rage brings to cap) is quite good in a low-to-mid magic setting, where uber fort save gear isn't exactly laying around for your enemies (no such thing as too much saves, I always say). Some seem to forget your standard "GI Jane/Joe Average" melee FTR has a STR 30, typically coming in AB 44-5 (45 is considered good melee AB around here for a straight-up melee build, and ours are high standards around here. I am personally addicted to AB/damage, like it a lot. You hit, you damage. It's quite simple, really. And at 45 (+6 Raging: 51) that is good.

When it comes to dev.crit--If take the dev.crit path on a non-RDD/melee build, a DC 42 / Bio cap 48 is really good. Hood is 1-off from that by my calculations (i.e., 10+ 1/2 char.level + STR mod: DC 41), but you rage it up +6 to DC 47 and need no equipment to do that. (Heh, care to check some Fort saves vs. a DC like that around here? Not so bad afterall, eh?

OK, not uber PG/Drake DC (pushing the 50+ cap), but then neither are the DCs of GI Jane/Joe the "good" melee warrior either. Perspective, perspective. Oh, and they don't have the Hps, nor can they self-buff ability stats either ...

Dev. Crit aside: What I love about Drake on barbarians --and based a whole series around back in the old ECB -- is that RDD gives you the STR as well as a nice boost to the AC which allows you to focus on other Barbarian things, like the CON for the Rage duration and EDR etc., so many nice synergies, and get to do so without having to give up Strength (i.e. AB/damage). Not to mention that INT makes for a smart looking and smart Half-Orc, too. Yeah, Raging RDD/Barbarians are not only cool, but rather effective, too.

In terms of IKD, would be nice but in terms of PvM/PvE only really need it for downing "huge" things like dragons, etc. Since you're going Sword-and-Big Board and have soak, could consider dropping the heavy armor prof. for it and wear chain or breastplate instead. (And yes, I know I said Big Barbarians carry the Big Axe or Big Knife always, but in this case, in light of the crit factor, makes sense Hood's going with the scimmy ... and if someone should laugh at a small knife of a big barbarian, well, careful: just might enrage Hood and then you'll be sorry ... heh, heh).

My Dragon Blades would be proud to stand beside and fight along-side Hood. Nicely done.

Rage, slash, Crit ON! ~ Tyr

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Great build where things really come together nicely

Is there a way to get ESF Intimidate for the + 10 boost to the Terrifying rage DC?
Will it be worth it to drop Mighty rage?
What are your thoughts on this?

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Thanks, Mick!

If you can cap the stats with items, then it might be, but the thing about Mighty Rage is that it gives you 3 extra and more powerful rages a day, as you only have 7 regular ones. I tend to use up almost if not all my rages before resting, so I particularly wouldn't bother. Also where I play, pretty much everyone but the very strong-willed bosses fail the saves against TR, and MR and EDR share a common requirement, so it's almost a no-brainer. That said, if you play somewhere where that ESF:Intimidate makes a difference and Mighty Rage doesn't, then I don't see why not.

I was considering yet another tweak to this build. I haven't decided on anything, and it may not be worth it in some places, but I was thinking of dropping 4 DEX for 2 INT and adding Taunt to the mix, but then I would lose a bit of AC which is not exactly top-notch. Still, let it be listed as a viable alternative.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Concavenator
posts.content: why pick Scimitar over 2 handed weapons? does shield give a lot of ac?

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content:
There are two reasons to pick scimitar over two handed weapons. The first you touched upon, a shield will give 3 ac plus its enchantment. On many player worlds this will give 8 ac over two-handed wielders. Plus any specials that the shield has.

Primarily I suspect the build chooses the scimitar, because the build goes for devastating critical, which depends upon the threat range of the weapon. The scimitar shares the largest threat range in the game. Thus it would threaten devastating critical more, and insta kill more enemies.
